RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_INT_STAT
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_INT_STAT is an interrupt status register. It shows the status of the masked interrupts.If certain bits of DMAC_INT_TC_STAT and DMAC_INT_ERR_STAT are masked at thesame time, the corresponding bit of DMAC_INT_STAT1 is also masked. Each bit ofDMAC_INT_STAT maps to one DMAC channel. When a bit is 1, it indicates that an interruptrequest is generated in the corresponding channel and the interrupt request may be an errorinterrupt or a terminal count interrupt.

Member.name: int_stat
Member.description:
Status of the masked interrupts of each DMA channel. Bit[7:0] map to channels 7–0.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated. The interrupt request may be an error interrupt or a terminal count interrupt.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_INT_TC_STAT
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_INT_TC_STAT is a terminal count interrupt status register. It shows the status of themasked terminal count interrupts. The corresponding mask bit is DMAC_CX_CONFIG[itc],where X is the channel number ranging from 0 to 7. The register must work withOffset Address

Member.name: nt_tc_stat
Member.description:
Status of the masked terminal count interrupts. Bit[7:0] map to channels 7–0.
0: No terminal count interrupt is generated.
1: A terminal count interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_INT_TC_CLR
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_INT_TC_CLR is a terminal count interrupt clear register. It is used to clear terminalcount interrupts.

Member.name: int_tc_clr
Member.description:
Terminal count interrupt clear. Bit[7:0] map to channels 7–0.
0: not clear
1: clear

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_INT_ERR_STAT
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_INT_ERR_STAT is an error interrupt status register. It shows the statuses of themasked error interrupts. The corresponding mask bit is DMAC_CX_CONFIG[ie]. Theregister must work with DMAC_INT_STAT.

Member.name: int_err_stat
Member.description:
Status of masked error interrupts. Bit[7:0] map to channels 7–0.
0: No error interrupt is generated.
1: An error interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_INT_ERR_CLR
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_INT_ERR_CLR is an error interrupt clear register. It is used to clear error interrupts.

Member.name: int_err_clr
Member.description:
Error interrupt clear. Bit[7:0] map to channels 7–0.
0: not clear
1: clear

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_RAW_INT_TC_STATUS
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_RAW_INT_TC_STATUS is a raw terminal count interrupt status register. It showsthe status of the raw terminal count interrupt of each channel.

Member.name: raw_int_tc_stat
Member.description:
Status of the raw terminal count interrupt of each channel. Bit[7:0] map to channels 7–0.
0: No terminal count interrupt is generated.
1: A terminal count interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_RAW_INT_ERR_STATUS
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_RAW_INT_ERR_STATUS is a raw error interrupt status register. It shows the statusof the raw error interrupt of each channel.

Member.name: raw_int_err_stat
Member.description:
Status of the raw error interrupt of each channel. Bit[7:0] map to channels 7–0.
0: No error interrupt is generated.
1: An error interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_ENBLD_CHNS
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_ENBLD_CHNS is a DMAC channel enable status register. It shows the enabledchannels.For example, if a bit of DMAC_ENBLD_CHNS is 1, it indicates that the correspondingchannel is enabled. The enable bit of DMAC_CX_CONFIG determines whether thecorresponding channel is enabled. When the DMA transfer of a channel is complete, the bit ofOffset Address

Member.name: enabled_channels
Member.description:
Channel enable. Bit[7:0] map to channels 7–0.
0: disabled
1: enabled

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_SOFT_BREQ
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_SOFT_BREQ is a DMA burst request register for software. It is used to controlwhether to generate a DMA burst request using software.When this register is read, the device that is requesting the DMA burst transfer can be queried.This register and any peripheral each can generate a DAM request.Note:Do not use a software DMA request and a hardware DMA request at the same time.

Member.name: soft_breq
Member.description:
Controls whether to generate a DMA burst transfer request using software. For the details about the request signal corresponding to each bit, see Table 3-45.
When this register is written:
0: No effect.
1: A DMA burst transfer request is generated. When the transfer is complete, the corresponding bit is cleared.
When this register is read:
0: The peripheral corresponding to the request signal DMACBREQ[15:0] does not send a DMA burst request.
1: The peripheral corresponding to the request signal DMACBREQ[15:0] is requesting a DMA burst transfer.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_SOFT_SREQ
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_SOFT_SREQ is a DMA single request register for software. It is used to controlwhether to generate a DMA single transfer request using software.When this register is read, the device that is requesting the DMA single transfer can bequeried. This register and any of the 16 DMA request input signals of the DMAC each cangenerate a DMA request.Note:Do not use a software DMA request and a hardware DMA request at the same time.

Member.name: soft_sreq
Member.description:
Controls whether to generate a DMA single transfer request using software. For details about the request signal corresponding to each bit, see Table 3-45.
When this register is written:
0: No effect.
1: A DMA single transfer request is generated. When the transfer is complete, the corresponding bit is cleared.
When this register is read:
0: The peripheral corresponding to the request signal DMACBREQ[15:0] does not send a DMA single request.
1: The peripheral corresponding to the request signal DMACBREQ[15:0] is requesting a DMA single transfer.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_SOFT_LBREQ
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_SOFT_LBREQ is a DMA last burst request register for software. It is used to controlwhether to generate a DMA last burst transfer request using software.

Member.name: soft_lbreq
Member.description:
Controls whether to generate a last burst request using software. For details about the request signal corresponding to each bit, see ?Table 3-45.
0: No effect.
1: A DMA last burst transfer request is generated. When the transfer is complete, the corresponding bit is cleared.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_SOFT_LSREQ
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_SOFT_LSREQ is a DMA last single request register for software. It is used to controlwhether to generate a DMA last single transfer request.

Member.name: soft_lsreq
Member.description:
Controls whether to generate a last single request using software. For details about the request signal corresponding to each bit, see ?Table 3-45.
0: No effect.
1: A DMA last single transfer request is generated. When the transfer is complete, the corresponding bit is cleared.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_CONFIG
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_CONFIG is a configuration register. It is used to configure DMAC operations. Youcan change the endian modes of the two master interfaces of the DMAC by writing to m1(bit[1]) and m2 (bit[2]) of this register. After reset, the modes of the two master interfaces areset to little endian.Note:Both two Masters work in little endian mode.

Member.name: m2
Member.description:
Endian mode of Master 2.
0: little endian mode
1: big endian mode

Member.name: m1
Member.description:
Endian mode of Master 1.
0: little endian mode
1: big endian mode

Member.name: e
Member.description:
DMAC enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_SYNC
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_SYNC is a synchronization register. It is used to enable or disable thesynchronization logic provided for DMA request signals.

Member.name: dmac_sync
Member.description:
Controls whether to synchronize the request signals. For the request signal corresponding to each bit, see Table 3-45.
0: enable the synchronization logic provided for the DMA request signals of the corresponding peripheral.
1: disable the synchronization logic provided for the DMA request signals of the corresponding peripheral.

Member.name: src_addr
Member.description: DMA source address.

Member.name: dest_addr
Member.description: DMA destination address.

Member.name: lli
Member.description: LLI. The bit[31:2]of the next LLI node address and the address bit[1:0] are both set to 0. A linked list address must be 4-byte aligned.

Member.name: r
Member.description: Reserved. This bit must be 0 during writes and must be masked during reads.

Member.name: lm
Member.description:
Master for loading the next LLI node.
0: Master1
1: Master2

Member.name: i
Member.description:
Terminal count interrupt enable. This bit determines whether the current LLI node triggers a terminal count interrupt.
0: not trigger
1: trigger

Member.name: prot
Member.description: HPROT[2:0] access protection signal transmitted by the Master.

Member.name: di
Member.description:
Destination address increment.
0: The destination address is not incremented
1: The destination address is incremented once after a data segment is transferred
If the destination device is a peripheral, the destination address is not incremented. If the destination device is a memory, the destination address is incremented.

Member.name: si
Member.description:
Source address increment.
0: The source address is not incremented
1: The source address is incremented once after a data segment is transferred
If the source device is a peripheral, the source address is not incremented. If the source device is a memory, the source address is incremented.

Member.name: d
Member.description:
Master for accessing the destination device.
0: The SPDIF, SIO0, SIO1, UART0, UART1, and SCI access the destination device using Master1.
1: The SPI flash, NAND flash, NOR flash, and DDRC access the destination device using Master 2.

Member.name: s
Member.description:
Master for accessing the source device.
0: The SPDIF, SIO0, SIO1, UART0, UART1, and SCI access the source device using Master1.
1: The SPI flash, NAND flash, NOR flash, and DDRC access the source device using Master2.

Member.name: dwidth
Member.description:
Transfer bit width of the destination device.
The transfer bit width is invalid if it is greater than the bit width of the Master.
The data widths of the destination and source devices can be different. The hardware automatically packs and unpacks the data.
For the mapping between the value of DWidth and the bit width, see Table 3-48.

Member.name: swidth
Member.description:
Transfer bit width of the source device.
The transfer bit width is invalid if it is greater than the bit width of the Master.
The data widths of the destination and source devices can be different. The hardware automatically packs and unpacks the data.
For the mapping between the value of SWidth and the bit width, see Table 3-48.

Member.name: dbsize
Member.description:
Burst size of the destination device.
Indicates the number of data segments to be transferred by the destination device in a burst transfer, that is, the number of transferred data segments when DMACCxBREQ is valid.
This value must be set to a burst size supported by the destination device. If the destination device is a memory, the value is set to the storage area size beyond the storage address boundary.
For the mapping between the value of DBSize and the transfer length, see Table 3-47.

Member.name: sbsize
Member.description:
Burst size of the source device.
Indicates the number of data segments to be transferred by the source device in a burst transfer, that is, the number of transferred data segments when DMACCxBREQ is valid.
The value must be set to a burst size supported by the source device. If the source device is a memory, the value is set to the storage area size beyond the storage address boundary.
For the mapping between the value of SBSize and the transfer length, see Table 3-47.

Member.name: transfersize
Member.description:
The DMA transfer size can be configured by writing to DMAC_CX_CONTROL only when the DMAC is a flow controller. The transfer size indicates the number of the data segments to be transferred by the source device.
When DMAC_CX_CONTROL is read, the number of data segments transferred through the bus connected to the destination device is obtained.
When a channel is active, no valid information is obtained when this register is read. This is because that after software obtains the register value, the value is changed during data transfer. Therefore, the register is read after the channel is enabled and data transfer is stopped.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description:
Reserved.
This bit must be 0 during writes and must be masked during reads.

Member.name: h
Member.description:
Halt bit.
0: The DMA request is allowed.
1: The subsequent DMA requests are ignored and the contents in the channel FIFO are completely transferred.
This bit can disable a DMA channel without data loss by working with the Active bit and the Channel Enable bit.

Member.name: a
Member.description:
Active bit.
0: There is no data in the channel FIFO.
1: There is data in the channel FIFO.
This bit can disable a DMA channel without data loss by working with the Halt bit and Channel Enable bit.

Member.name: l
Member.description:
Lock bit.
0: Disable lock transfer on the bus.
1: Enable lock transfer on the bus.

Member.name: itc
Member.description:
Terminal count interrupt mask bit.
0: Mask the terminal count interrupts of the channel.
1: Do not mask the terminal count interrupts of the channel.

Member.name: ie
Member.description:
Error interrupt mask bit.
0: Mask the error interrupts of the channel.
1: Do not mask the error interrupts of the channel.

Member.name: flow_cntrl
Member.description:
Flow control and transfer type field.
This field is used to specify the flow controller and the transfer type. The flow controller can be the DMAC, source device, or destination device.
The transfer type can be memory to peripheral, peripheral to memory, peripheral to peripheral, or memory to memory. For details, see Table 3-50.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description:
Reserved.
This bit must be 0 during writes and must be masked during reads.

Member.name: dest_peripheral
Member.description:
Destination device. This field is used to select a peripheral request signal as the request signal of the DMA destination device of the channel.
If the destination device for DMA transfer is a memory, this field is ignored.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description:
Reserved.
This bit must be 0 during writes and must be masked during reads.

Member.name: src_peripheral
Member.description:
Source device. This field is used to select a peripheral request signal as the request signal of the DMA source device of the channel.
If the source device for DMA transfer is a memory, this field is ignored.

Member.name: e
Member.description:
Channel enable bit. The current status of a channel can be queried by reading this register or DMACEnbldChns.
0: disabled
1: enabled
Clearing this bit can disable a channel. When this bit is cleared, the current bus continues to transfer data until all data is transferred. Then, the channel is disabled and the remaining data in the FIFO is lost. When the last LLI is transferred or an error occurs during transfer, the channel is also disabled and this bit is cleared. If you want to disable a channel without data loss, the Halt bit must be set to 1 so the subsequent DMA requests are ignored by the channel. After this, the Active bit must be polled until its value becomes 0. This indicates that there is no data in the channel FIFO. At this time, the Enable bit can be cleared.
To enable a channel by setting this bit to 1, you must reinitialize the channel. If a channel is enabled by setting this bit to 1 only, unexpected results may occur.

Member.description: Reserved. Reading this field returns 0, and writing to this field has no effect.

Member.description: Operating parameter of the internal MPLL of the PHY. This field needs to be used with mpll_ncy and indicates the used multiplier.

Member.name: mpll_prescale
Member.description:
When the reference clock is changed, this value also needs to be changed.
00: ref_clk is used as it is.
01: ref_clk is multiplied by 2.
10: ref_clk is divided by 2.
11: reserved

Member.name: mpll_ss_en
Member.description:
Spread spectrum enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled
If refclk is processed through the spread spectrum technology, this bit must be set to 0. This bit is generally valid for SATA_PHY only.

Member.name: mpll_ss_sel
Member.description:
Spread spectrum select.
Reserved. This bit must be set to 0.

Member.name: pcie0_slv_device_type
Member.description:
Type of the PCIe0 (X1) controller.
0000: PCIe endpoint device
0001: legacy PCIe endpoint device
0100: root port of PCIe root complex
Other values: reserved

Member.name: pcie0_slv_resp_err_map
Member.description:
PCIe0 (X1) controller. The slave device provides responses when any of the following errors occurs:
bit[22]: CPL UR
bit[23]: not used
bit[24]: CPL CRS
bit[25]: CPL poisoned
bit[26]: CPL ECRC
bit[27]: CPL abort (MLF or UC)
CPL = completion
UR = unsupported request
CRS = completion retry request
UC = unexpected completion
MLF = malformed
ECRC = end-to-end 32-bit CRC

Member.name: pcie0_slv_awmisc_info
Member.description:
PCIe0 (X1) controller.
bit[4:0]: type of an AXI transaction
bit[5]: BCM of an AXI transaction
bit[6]: EP of an AXI transaction
bit[7]: TD of an AXI transaction
bit[9:8]: ATTR of an AXI transaction
bit[12:10]: TC of an AXI transaction
bit[20:13]: MSG code of an AXI transaction
BCM = byte counter modified
EP = end-to-end TLP
TD = TLP digest
ATTR = attribute
TC = traffic class
MSG = message
bit[21]: whether to select the configured transmission type
0: select the type that is calculated by using the address mapping
1: select the type configured by the register, that is, bit[4:0]

Member.name: pcie0_mstr_rmisc_info

PCIE0 (X1) controller.
The AXI master reads the responded MISC information.
bit[15:14]: attributes of an AXI response
bit[16]: bad EOT of an AXI response. It is assigned to the signal native PCIE core to drop this response.
bit[19:17]: TC of an AXI response
bit[20]: BCM of an AXI response
bit[21]: EP of an AXI response
bit[22]: TD of an AXI response
bit[25:23]: function number of an AXI response

Member.name: pcie0_mstr_bmisc_info
Member.description:
PCIe0 (X1) controller.
The AXI master writes the responded MISC information.
bit[1:0]: attributes of an AXI response
bit[2]: bad EOT of an AXI response. It is assigned to the signal native PCIE core to drop this response.
bit[5:3]: TC of an AXI response
bit[6]: BCM of an AXI response
bit[7]: EP of an AXI response
bit[8]: TD of an AXI response
bit[11:9]: function number of an AXI response
bit[13:12]: master response error map

Member.description:
PCIE1 (X2) controller.
Reference clock remove request
0: valid
1: invalid

Member.name: pcie0_pm_status
Member.description:
PCIE1 (X2) controller.
PME state bit of PMCSR.
0: invalid
1: valid

Member.name: pcie0_hp_msi
Member.description:
PCIe0 (X1) controller.
When the following conditions are met, the core can make the signal take effect (pulses in a cycle):
MSI or MSI-X is enabled.
Hot-plug interrupts are enabled in the slot control register.
Any bit in the slot status register changes from 0 to 1 and the associated event notification is enabled in the slot control register.

Member.name: pcie0_hp_int
Member.description:
PCIe0 (X1) controller.
When the following conditions are met, the core can make the signal take effect:
The INTx Assertion Disable bit in the command register is 0.
Hot-plug interrupts are enabled in the slot control register.
Any bit in the Slot Status register is equal to 1, and the associated event notification is enabled in the slot control register.

Member.name: pcie0_hp_pme
Member.description:
PCIe0 (X1) controller.
When the following conditions are met, the core can make hp_pme take effect:
The PME Enable bit in the power management control and status register is set to 1.
Any bit in the slot status register transitions from 0 to 1 and the associated event notification is enabled in the slot control register.

Member.name: pcie0_cfg_eml_control
Member.description:
PCIe0 (X1) controller.
Electromechanical interlock control. The state of the Electromechanical Interlock Control bit in the slot control register.

Member.name: pcie0_wake
Member.description:
PCIe0 (X1) controller.
Wake Up. Wake up from power management unit. The core generates wake to request the system to restore power and clock when a beacon has been detected. Wake is an active high signal and its rising edge should be detected to drive the WAKE# on the connector. Assertion of wake could be a clock or multiple clock cycles.

Member.name: pcie0_xmlh_link_up
Member.description:
PCIe0 (X1) controller.
PHY link up/down indicator.
0: link down
1: link up

Member.name: pcie0_cfg_sys_err_rc
Member.description:
PCIe0 (X1) controller.
Indicates that a system error is detected (pulses within a clock cycle).
0: invalid
1: valid

Member.name: pcie0_cfg_aer_int_msg_num
Member.description:
PCIe0 (X1) controller.
This signal derives from bit[31:27] of the root error status register and is valid only when MSI or MSI-X is enabled.

Member.name: pcie0_cfg_aer_rc_err_msi
Member.description:
PCIe0 (X1) controller.
When the following conditions are met, the core can make the signal take effect within a clock cycle:
MSI or MSI-X is enabled.
A reported error condition causes a bit to be set in the root error status register.
The associated error message reporting enable bit is set in the root error command register.

Member.name: pcie0_cfg_aer_rc_err_int
Member.description:
PCIe0 (X1) controller.
When a bit of the root error status register is set to 1 due to an error and the Enable bit of the root error command register is valid, this signal takes effect.

Member.name: hclkdivsel
Member.description:
Ratio relationship between the CPU clock, L2 cache clock, and AXI bus clock. Before switching the clock ratio, you need to switch the system mode to slow mode.
X00: A9:L2 cache =1:1
L2 cache:AXI = 2:1
X01: reserved. The system cannot work if this value is set.
X10: reserved. The system cannot work if this value is set.
X11: A9:L2 cache =3:2
L2 cache:AXI =1:1
Note: If you want to switch the system mode from the normal to the slow mode, you must set this field to X00.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description: Reserved. Reading this field returns 0, and writing to this field has no effect.

Member.description:
Address remap clear.
0: not clear
1: clear

Member.name: reserved

Member.name: modestatus
Member.description:
Mode status. Reading this field returns the current operating mode of the system.
0000: reserved
0001: doze
0011: XTAL CTL
1011: SWtoXTAL
1001: SWfromXTAL
0010: slow
0110: PLL CTL
1110: SWtoPLL
1010: SWfromPLL
0100: normal
Other values: reserved

100: normal
Other values: reserved

RegisterGroup.name: SC_SYSRES
RegisterGroup.description: SC_SYSRES is a system status register. When any value is written to this register, the systemcontroller sends a system soft reset request to the reset module. Then the reset module resetsthe system.

Member.name: softresreq
Member.description: The system is reset when any value is written to this register.

RegisterGroup.name: SC_XTALCTRL
RegisterGroup.description: SC_XTALCTRL is a crystal oscillator control register. This register is used to control thestable time after the clock module is initialized, that is, the wait time spent switching themode from XTAL CTL to SWtoXTAL.

Member.name: xtaltime
Member.description:
Wait time spent switching the crystal oscillator clock.
The value of this field specifies the wait time when the system is switched from the XTAL CTL mode to the SWtoXTAL mode.
The wait cycle is calculated as follows: (65,536 – xtaltime) x T30K. T30K indicates the 30 kHz low-frequency clock cycle.
Note: To speed up the switching from the doze mode to the slow mode, set the value of xtaltime to 0xFFFF. That is, the system is stable after the crystal oscillator is powered on.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description: Reserved. Reading this field returns the written value.

RegisterGroup.name: SC_APLLCTRL
RegisterGroup.description: SC_APLLCTRL is an APLL control register. It is used to set the APLL stable wait time. Theclock frequency of the APLL is controlled by the corresponding bits of SC_APLLCFGSTAT1and SC_APLLCFGSTAT0.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description: Reserved. Reading this field returns 0, and writing to this field has no effect.

Member.name: plltime
Member.description:
Stable wait time of the APLL.
The wait time refers to the period during which the PLL output becomes stable after the PLL is started. In other words, the wait time is the period during which the system is switch from the PLLCTL mode to the SWtoPLL mode.
The timeout time is calculated as follows: (33,554,432 - plltime) x TXIN. TXIN indicates the clock cycle of the external crystal oscillator.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description: Reserved. Reading this field returns 0, and writing to this field has no effect.

RegisterGroup.name: TIMER0_LOAD
RegisterGroup.description:
TIMERx_LOAD is an initial count value register. It is used to set the initial count value of each timer. Each timer (timer0–timer7) has one such register.
When a timer is in periodic mode and the count value reaches 0, the value of TIMERx_LOAD is reloaded to the counter. When a value is written to TIMERx_LOAD, the value of the current counter is changed to the input value on the next rising edge of the TIMCLK enabled by TIMCLKENx.
Note:
? The minimum valid value written to TIMERx_LOAD is 1.
? When 0 is written to TIMERx_LOAD, the dual-timer module generates an interrupt immediately.
When a value is written to TIMERx_BGLOAD, the value of TIMERx_LOAD is overwritten, but the current value of the timer remains.
If values are written to TIMERx_BGLOAD and TIMERx_LOAD before the rising edge of TIMCLK enabled by TIMCLKENx is reached, the value of the counter on the next rising edge is changed to the written value of TIMERx_LOAD. From then on, when the counter reaches 0, the last value written to TIMERx_BGLOAD or TIMERx_LOAD is reloaded.
After TIMERx_BGLOAD and TIMERx_LOAD are written twice respectively, the written value of TIMERx_BGLOAD is returned when TIMERx_LOAD is read.

Member.name: timer0_load
Member.description: Initial count value of timer0.

RegisterGroup.name: TIMER1_LOAD
RegisterGroup.description:
TIMERx_LOAD is an initial count value register. It is used to set the initial count value of each timer. Each timer (timer0–timer7) has one such register.
When a timer is in periodic mode and the count value reaches 0, the value of TIMERx_LOAD is reloaded to the counter. When a value is written to TIMERx_LOAD, the value of the current counter is changed to the input value on the next rising edge of the TIMCLK enabled by TIMCLKENx.
Note:
? The minimum valid value written to TIMERx_LOAD is 1.
? When 0 is written to TIMERx_LOAD, the dual-timer module generates an interrupt immediately.
When a value is written to TIMERx_BGLOAD, the value of TIMERx_LOAD is overwritten, but the current value of the timer remains.
If values are written to TIMERx_BGLOAD and TIMERx_LOAD before the rising edge of TIMCLK enabled by TIMCLKENx is reached, the value of the counter on the next rising edge is changed to the written value of TIMERx_LOAD. From then on, when the counter reaches 0, the last value written to TIMERx_BGLOAD or TIMERx_LOAD is reloaded.
After TIMERx_BGLOAD and TIMERx_LOAD are written twice respectively, the written value of TIMERx_BGLOAD is returned when TIMERx_LOAD is read.

Member.name: timer1_load
Member.description: Initial count value of timer1.

RegisterGroup.name: TIMER0_VALUE
RegisterGroup.description:
TIMERx_VALUE is a current count value register. It shows the current value of the counter that is being decremented. Each timer (timer0–timer7) has one such register.
After a value is written to TIMERx_LOAD, TIMERx_VALUE immediately shows the newly loaded value of the counter in the PCLK domain without waiting for the next TIMCLK clock edge enabled by TIMCLKENx.
Note:
When a timer is in 16-bit mode, the upper 16 bits of the 32-bit TIMERx_VALUE are not set to 0 automatically. If the timer is switched from 32-bit mode to 16-bit mode and no data is written to TIMERx_LOAD in 16-bit mode, the upper 16 bits of TIMERx_VALUE may not be 0.

Member.name: timer0_value
Member.description: Current count value of timer0 that is being decremented.

RegisterGroup.name: TIMER1_VALUE
RegisterGroup.description:
TIMERx_VALUE is a current count value register. It shows the current value of the counter that is being decremented. Each timer (timer0–timer7) has one such register.
After a value is written to TIMERx_LOAD, TIMERx_VALUE immediately shows the newly loaded value of the counter in the PCLK domain without waiting for the next TIMCLK clock edge enabled by TIMCLKENx.
Note:
When a timer is in 16-bit mode, the upper 16 bits of the 32-bit TIMERx_VALUE are not set to 0 automatically. If the timer is switched from 32-bit mode to 16-bit mode and no data is written to TIMERx_LOAD in 16-bit mode, the upper 16 bits of TIMERx_VALUE may not be 0.

Member.name: timer0_value
Member.description: Current count value of timer1 that is being decremented

Member.name: timerpre
Member.description:
Timer prescaling divider set bit.
00: no prescaling. That is, the clock frequency of the timer is divided by 1.
01: 4-level prescaling. That is, the clock frequency of the timer is divided by 16.
10: 8-level prescaling, namely, dividing the clock frequency of the timer by 256.
11: undefined. If the bits are set to 11, 8-level prescaling is considered. That is, the clock frequency of the timer is divided by 256.

1: 32-bit counter

1: one-shot mode

RegisterGroup.name: TIMER0_INTCLR
RegisterGroup.description:
TIMERx_INTCLR is an interrupt clear register. The interrupt status of the corresponding counter is cleared after a value is written to this register. Each timer (timer0–timer7) has one such register.
Caution:
This register is write-only. When any value is written to this register, the timer interrupts are cleared. In addition, no written value is recorded in this register and no default reset value is defined.

Member.name: timer0_intclr
Member.description: Writing this register clears the output interrupts of timer0.

RegisterGroup.description:

This register is write-only. When any value is written to this register, the timer interrupts are cleared. In addition, no written value is recorded in this register and no default reset value is defined.

Member.name: timer1_intclr
Member.description: Writing this register clears the output interrupts of timer1.

RegisterGroup.name: TIMER0_BGLOAD
RegisterGroup.description: TIMERx_BGLOAD is an initial count value register in periodic mode. Each timer (timer0–timer7) has one such register.This register contains the initial count value of the timer. In periodic mode, this register isused to reload an initial count value when the count value of the timer reaches 0.The register also provides another method of accessing TIMERx_LOAD. After a value iswritten to TIMERx_BGLOAD, the timer, however, does not count starting from the new inputvalue immediately.TIMER0_BGLOAD

Member.description: Initial count value of the watchdog counter.

RegisterGroup.name: WDG_VALUE
RegisterGroup.description: WDG_VALUE is a current count value register It is used to read the current count value ofthe internal counter of the watchdog.

Member.name: wdogvalue
Member.description: Current count value of the watchdog counter.

RegisterGroup.name: WDG_CONTROL
RegisterGroup.description: WDG_CONTROL is a control register. It is used to enable or disable the watchdog andcontrol the interrupt and reset functions of the watchdog.

Member.name: resen
Member.description:
Output enable of the watchdog reset signal.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: inten
Member.description:
Output enable of the watchdog interrupt signal.
0: The counter stops counting, the current count value keeps unchanged, and the watchdog is disabled.
1: The counter, interrupt and watchdog are enabled.

RegisterGroup.name: WDG_INTCLR
RegisterGroup.description: WDG_INTCLR is an interrupt clear register. It is used to clear watchdog interrupts so thewatchdog can reload an initial value for counting. This register is write-only. When any valueis written to this register, the watchdog interrupts are cleared. No written value is recorded inthis register and no default reset value is defined.

Member.name: wdg_intclr
Member.description: Writing any value to this register clears the watchdog interrupts and enables the watchdog to reload an initial count value from WDG_LOAD to restart counting.

RegisterGroup.name: WDG_RIS
RegisterGroup.description: WDG_RIS is a raw interrupt status register. It shows the raw interrupt status of the watchdog.

Member.name: wdogris
Member.description:
Status of the raw interrupts of the watchdog. When the count value reaches 0, this bit is set to 1.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: WDG_MIS
RegisterGroup.description: WDG_MIS is a masked interrupt status register. It shows the masked interrupt status of thewatchdog.

Member.name: wdogmis
Member.description:
Status of the masked interrupts of the watchdog.
0: No interrupt is generated or an interrupt is masked.
1: An interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: WDG_LOCK
RegisterGroup.description: WDG_LOCK is a lock register. It is used to control the write and read permissions to thewatchdog registers.

Member.name: wdg_lock
Member.description:
Writing 0x1ACC_E551 to this register enables the write permissions to all the registers.
Writing other values disables the write permissions to all the registers.
When this register is read, the lock status rather than the written value of this register is returned.
0x0000_0000: The write permission is available (unlocked).
0x0000_0001: The write permission is unavailable (locked).

Member.name: init_arefnum

Number of auto-refresh operations when the DDRn SDRAM is being initialized.
0x0–0x2: two
0x3–0xF: n (n = 3, 4, …, 15)

Member.name: pd_prd
Member.description:
Power down cycle configuration of the DDRn SDRAM. When the DDRC does not receive any command in continuous pd_prd cycles, it forces the DDRn SDRAM to enter the low-power mode; when a command is received, the DDRC forces the DDRn SDRAM to exit the low-power mode.
0x00: one clock cycle
0x01–0xFF: n clock cycles (n = 1, 2, 3, …, 255)
Note: This parameter is valid only when pd_en is 1.

Member.name: sr_cc
Member.description:
DDRn SDRAM clock control in self-refresh mode.
0: The DDRn SDRAM clock is enabled.
1: The DDRn SDRAM clock is disabled.

Member.name: pd_cc
Member.description:
DDRn SDRAM clock control in power down mode.
0: The DDRn SDRAM clock is enabled.
1: The DDRn SDRAM clock is disabled.
Note: This parameter is valid only when the connected external DDR is a mobile DDRn SDRAM.

Member.name: pd_en
Member.description:
Automatic low-power enable of the DDRn SDRAM.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: rank
Member.description:
Rank configuration of the DDRC.
00: 1 rank
01: 2 ranks
Other values: reserved

Member.name: dram_type

Member.name: mem_width
Member.description:
Bit width of the storage data bus.

01: 32 bits

Member.name: brst_a12
Member.description:
DDR3 SDRAM A12 command enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled
Note: The recommended value is 0.

Member.name: brstlen
Member.description:
Burst length of the DDRC.
0: burst 4
1: burst 8
The burst length of the DDR2 SDRAM can be set to burst 4 or burst 8.
The burst length of the DDR3 SDRAM can be set to burst 8.

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_CONFIG1
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_CONFIG1 is DDRC function configuration register 1.

Member.name: wr_rcv_mode
Member.description:
Mode of receiving the write command over the DDRC AXI port.
0: The write command is received directly.
1: The write command is received only after the expected write data arrives.

Member.name: exclu_en
Member.description:
Exclusive command enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: lock_en
Member.description:
WRA command lock enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: aref_mode
Member.description:
Auto-refresh mode select.
0: An auto-refresh operation is performed every one tREFI period.
1: Eight auto-refresh operations are performed every nine tREFI periods.

Member.name: wrlvl_en
Member.description:
Auto-control enable of the DDR3 write level hardware.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: read_mode
Member.description:
Read mode select of the DDRC.
0: associated read mode
1: delay read mode
The associated read mode is a mode in which the DDRC samples data based on the data valid signal from the DDRn SDRAM.
The delay read mode is a mode in which the DDRC samples the data from the DDRn SDRAM after the internal delay of the DDRC.
Note: This bit must be set to 0 when DDRC_DTRCTRL[train_mode] is set to 0.

Member.name: clkratio
Member.description:
Operating mode of the DDRC.
0: The ratio of the frequency of the DDRC to the frequency of the DDRn SDRAM is 1:1.
0: The ratio of the frequency of the DDRC to the frequency of the DDRn SDRAM is 1:2.
Note: The ratio can be set to 1:1 only in this version.

Member.name: ecc_en
Member.description: Reserved. This bit is not supported in this version.

Member.name: zqc_en
Member.description:
DDR3 SDRAM ZQ enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled
Note: This bit is valid for the DDR3 SDRAM only and is set to 1 by default.

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_CMDCFG
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_CMDCFG is a DDRn SDRAM command configuration register.

Member.name: cmd_mrs
Member.description: Configured value of the DDRC when the load mode register (LMR) command is configured.

Member.name: cmd_ba
Member.description: Configured value of the DDRC when the LMR command is configured.

Member.name: cmd_rank
Member.description:
Rank of running commands.
0: The configuration command is executed.
1: The configuration command is not executed.
Each bit controls rank.

Member.name: cmd_type
Member.description:
DDR command configuration.
00: enter the deep power down mode
01: exit the deep power down mode
10: LMR command
11: ZQCL

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_CMDEXE
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_CMDEXE is a DDRC software configuration command start register.

Member.name: cmd_req
Member.description:
Request of executing the configuration command of the DDRC.
0: The command is not executed or the parameter is cleared automatically after the command is executed.
1: The command is requested to be executed.

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_RNKCFG
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_RNKCFG is a DDRn SDRAM feature configuration register.

Member.name: mem_map
Member.description:
Address translation mode of the DDRn SDRAM.
00: {Rank,Row,Ba,Col,DW} = AXI_Address
01: {Rank,Ba,Row,Col,DW} = AXI_Address
Other values: reserved

Member.name: mem_bank
Member.description:
Number of banks of a single DDRn SDRAM.
0: 4 banks
1: 8 banks

Member.name: mem_row
Member.description:
Bit width of the row address of a single DDRn SDRAM.
000: 11 bits
001: 12 bits
010: 13 bits
011: 14 bits
100: 15 bits
101: 16 bits
Other values: reserved

Member.name: mem_col
Member.description:
Bit width of the column address of a single DDRn SDRAM.
000: 8 bits
001: 9 bits
010: 10 bits
011: 11 bits
100: 12 bits
Other values: reserved

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_TIMING0
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_TIMING0 is DDR timing parameter register 0.

Member.name: tmrd
Member.description:
Count of wait cycles of LSM command.
0x0–0x1: one clock cycle.
0x2–0xF: n clock cycles (n = 2, 3, …, 15)

Member.name: trrd
Member.description:
Count of wait cycles from ACT bank A to ACT bank B.
0x0–0x1: one clock cycle
0x2–0xF: n clock cycles (n = 2, 3, ..., 15)

Member.name: trp
Member.description:
Count of wait cycles of the disable command (PRE period).
0x0–0x1: one clock cycle
0x2–0xF: n clock cycles (n = 2, 3, ..., 15)

Member.name: trcd
Member.description:
Count of wait cycles from the ACT bank command to the read or write bank command.
0x0–0x3: three clock cycles
0x4–0xF: n clock cycles (n = 4, 5, …, 15)

Member.name: trc
Member.description:
Count of wait cycles from an ACT bank command to the next ACT bank command.
0x00–0x01: one clock cycle
0x02-0x3F: n clock cycles (n = 2, 3, …, 63)

Member.name: tras
Member.description:
Count of wait cycles from the ACT bank command to the PRE disable command.
0x00–0x01: one clock cycle
0x02-0x0F: n clock cycles (n = 2, 3, ..., 15)

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_TIMING1
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_TIMING1 is DDR timing parameter register 1.

Member.name: tsre
Member.description:
Count of wait cycles from the self-refresh exit command to the read command.
0x0: one clock cycle
0x01–0xFF: n x 2 clock cycles (n = 2, 3, …, 255)
When the DDR3 SDRAM is used, the value is set to tXSDLL.

Member.name: trdlat
Member.description:
Inherent delay of the DDRPHY.
0x0–0xF: n + 1 clock cycles (n = 2, 3, ..., 15)
When the Dophin DDRPHY is used, the value is set to 0x5.

Member.name: trtw
Member.description:
Delay from the last read data segment to the first written data segment.
0x0–0x1: one clock cycle
0x2-0xF: n + 1 clock cycles (n = 2, 3, ..., 15)

Member.name: twl
Member.description:
Count of wait cycles from the write command to the write data.
0x0–0x1: one clock cycle
0x2–0xF: n clock cycles (n = 2, 3, ..., 15)
For example, 0x3 indicates three clock cycles.
Note: In DDR2 mode, tw1 is set to tcl – 1 and the condition of twl – taond ≥ 1 must be true.

Member.name: tcl
Member.description:
DDR CL from the read command to the read data.
0x0–0x1: one clock cycle
0x2-0xF: n clock cycles (n = 2, 3, ..., 15)

Member.name: trfc
Member.description:
Count of wait cycles of the AREF period or AREF to the ACT command. The register can be set to the maximum value max{trfc,tzqcs}.
0x00–0x01: one clock cycle
0x02–0xFF: n clock cycles (n = 2, 3, …, 255)

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_TIMING2
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_TIMING2 is DDR timing parameter register 2.

Member.name: tcke
Member.description:
Minimum period of maintaining the low-power mode.
0x0–0x1: one clock cycle
0x2–0xF: n clock cycles (n = 2, 3, ..., 15)
The value needs to be set to the maximum value among tCKESR, tCKSRE, tCKSRX, and tCKE.
When the Dophin DDRPHY is used, the value of this register needs to be set to max{tCKSRx,tCKE} + 3.

Member.name: twtr
Member.description:
Count of wait cycles of the last write-to-read command.
0x0–0x1: one clock cycle
0x2–0xF: n clock cycles (n = 2, 3, ..., 15)
For example, 0x3 indicates three clock cycles.

Member.name: twr
Member.description:
Count of wait cycles of write recovery.
0x0–0x1: one clock cycle
0x2–0xF: n clock cycles (n = 2, 3, ..., 15)
For example, 0x3 indicates three clock cycles.

Member.name: tfaw
Member.description:
Count of clock cycles of four continuous activation commands.
0x00-0x3F: n clock cycles (n = 0, 1, …, 63)
For example, 0x14 indicates 20 clock cycles.

Member.name: taref
Member.description:
Count of auto-refresh cycle.
0x000: forbidden
0x001–0x7FF: The auto-refresh cycle of the DDRn SDRAM is 16 x n clock cycles (n = 1, 2, …, 2048).
For example, 0x008 indicates 128 clock cycles (16 x 8).
The value depends on the operating frequency of the DDRn SDRAM.

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_TIMING3
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_TIMING3 is DDR timing parameter register 3.

Member.name: tzq_prd
Member.description:
Count of ZQCS command cycles.
0x000: The ZQCS command is forbidden.
0x00-0x3F: n AREF cycles (n = 1, 2, …, 1023)
The count of ZQCS command cycle is equal to n x taref clock cycles.

Member.name: tzqinit
Member.description:
Count of delay cycles during ZQ initialization.
0x0–0x1FF: n + 1 clock cycle (n = 0, 1, 2, …, 511)
The value needs to be set to the maximum value between tZQINIT and tDLLK.

Member.name: taond
Member.description:
Count of ODT enable/disable cycles.
In DDR2 mode (taond/taofd):
0x0: 2/2.5
0x1: 3/3.5
0x2: 4/4.5
0x3: 5/5.5
Other values: reserved
In DDR3 mode, the value is set to tWL – 1.

Member.name: txard
Member.description:
Count of wait cycles of exiting the DDR low-power mode.
0x0–0xF: n clock cycles. The letter n indicates the corresponding decimal value (n = 0, 1, …, 15).
For example, 0x7 indicates seven clock cycles.
The value is set to the maximum value among tXP, tXARD, tXARDS, and tXS.
In DDR3 mode, when the register is set to tXS, txard only needs to be set to an equivalent clock cycle of 10 ns.

Member.name: trtp
Member.description:
Wait delay from the read command to the disable command.
000–010: two clock cycles
011–111: n clock cycles (n = 3, 4, …, 7)

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_TIMING4
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_TIMING4 is DDR timing parameter register 4.

Member.name: twlo
Member.description:
DDR3 write level status delay parameter (configured in DDR3 mode only).
0x0–0x1: one clock cycle
0x2–0xF: n clock cycles (n = 2, 3, ..., 15)
The parameter is equal to twlo + twloe.

Member.name: twldqsen
Member.description:
DDR3 write level start delay parameter.
0x0–0x1: one clock cycle
0x02-0x3F: n clock cycles (n = 2, 3, …, 63)

Member.name: twlmrd
Member.description:
Valid delay parameter of the initial DDR3 write level DQS.
0x0–0x1: one clock cycle
0x02-0x3F: n clock cycles (n = 2, 3, …, 63)

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_DTRADDR
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_DTRADDR is a DDRC gating training address configuration register.

Member.name: train_row
Member.description: Row address of the DDRn SDRAM used in the gating position training. When the row address is less than 16 bits, the upper bits are stuffed with 0s.

Member.name: train_bank
Member.description: Bank address of the DDRn SDRAM used in the gating position training. When the bank address is less than three bits, the upper bits are stuffed with 0s.

Member.name: train_col
Member.description: Column address of the DDRn SDRAM used in the gating position training. When the column address is less than 13 bits, the upper bits are stuffed with 0s.

When the DDRC performs training, data must be transferred in DDR BL8 mode in each read or write operation.
Note: The data configured for the upper four bits and lower four bits of each byte must be different.

Member.name: dtr_byte2
Member.description: Gating training data configuration of the DDRC.

Member.name: dtr_byte1
Member.description: Gating training data configuration of the DDRC.

Member.name: dtr_byte0
Member.description: Gating training data configuration of the DDRC.

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_DTRDATA1

Member.name: dtr_byte7
Member.description:
Gating training data configuration 1 of the DDRC.
When the DDRC performs training, data must be transferred in DDR BL8 mode in each read or write operation.
Note: The data configured for the upper four bits and lower four bits of each byte must be different.

Member.name: dtr_byte6
Member.description: Gating training data configuration of the DDRC.

Member.name: dtr_byte5
Member.description: Gating training data configuration of the DDRC.

Member.name: dtr_byte4
Member.description: Gating training data configuration of the DDRC.

Member.name: dt_byte
Member.description:
Byte training enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled
bit[31:24]: training enable of DDRC byte7 to DDRC byte0

Member.name: train_start_pos
Member.description:
Start position of the gating training.
0x0-0x5: n clock cycles (n = 0, 1, …, 5)
Other values: reserved

Member.name: train_rank
Member.description:
Number of ranks in the gating training.
0x0–0x1: n + 1 ranks (n = 0, 1)
Note: Other configurations are not supported in this version.

Member.name: train_mode
Member.description:
Gating training mode.
0: dophin training mode
1: common training mode

Member.name: dt_limit
Member.description:
DQS gating shift control.
00: shift 0°
01: shift 90°
10: shift 180°
11: 270°

Member.name: track_en
Member.description:
Auto-refresh enable for the gating position.
0: disabled
1: enabled
Note: A read operation is required between two training operations and the continuous length of the accessed data must be greater than DDR burst 8.

Member.name: train_en
Member.description:
Gating position training enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: itm_rst
Member.description:
ITM reset signal of the DDRn SDRAM.
0: valid
1: invalid

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_DTRPRD
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_DTRPRD is a DDRC gating track period configuration register.

Member.name: track_prd
Member.description:
Auto-update period configuration of the DQS gating. The DDRC tracks the gating position in the configured period.
0x0: one AREF period
0x1–0x7FF: n + 1 AREF periods (n = 1, 2, …, 2047)

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_DTRGATE
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_DTRGATE is a DDRC gating phase position register.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description:
Reserved.
Note: This register cannot be read or written continuously.

Member.name: gate_sel
Member.description:
Gating phase position of the DDRC.
00: 0°
01: 90°
10: 180°
11: 270°
bit[2 x (N + 1) – 1:2 x N]: gating phase of DDRC byte N (N = 0, 1, …, 7)

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_DTRLAT

Member.name: sys_lat
Member.description:
Count of gating delay cycles of the DDRC.
0x0-0x5: n clock cycles (n = 0, 1, …, 5)
Other values: reserved
bit[4 x (N + 1) – 1:4 x N]: gating phase of DDRC byteN (N = 0, 1, …, 7)
Note: This register cannot be read or written continuously.

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_DTRSTATUS
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_DTRSTATUS is a DDRC gating status register.

Member.name: dtr_st
Member.description:
Phase shift status of the byte gating position.
00: shift 0°
01: shift 90°
10: shift 180°
11: 270°

Member.name: dtr_ok
Member.description:
Gating training status.
0: An error occurs during training.
1: No error occurs during training.
bit[15:8]: The training of DDRC byte7 to DDRC byte0 is successful.

Member.name: dtr_err
Member.description:
Auto tracking error status of the gating position.
0: No error occurs during tracking.
1: An error occurs during tracking.
bit[7:0]: The training of DDRC byte7 to DDRC byte0 is incorrect.

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_AXISTATUS

Member.name: axi_st2
Member.description:
Status of DDRC bus interface 2.
0: Idle.
1: A command is being executed.

Member.name: axi_st1
Member.description:
Status of DDRC bus interface 1.
0: Idle.

Member.name: axi_st0

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_ODTCFG
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_ODTCFG is a DDR ODT feature configuration register.

Member.name: rodt1
Member.description:
Read ODT configuration of rank1.
0: disabled
1: enabled
bit[21]: rank1 ODT
bit[20]: rank0 ODT
This parameter is used to determine whether to enable the read ODT pins of other ranks when rank1 is read.

Member.name: rodt0
Member.description:
Read ODT configuration of rank0.
0: disabled
1: enabled
bit[17]: rank1 ODT
bit[16]: rank0 ODT
This parameter is used to determine whether to enable the read ODT pins of other ranks when rank0 is read.

Member.name: wodt1
Member.description:
Write ODT configuration of rank1.
0: disabled
1: enabled
bit[5]: rank1 ODT
bit[4]: rank0 ODT
This parameter is used to determine whether to enable the write ODT pins of other ranks when rank1 is written.

Member.name: wodt0
Member.description:
Write ODT configuration of rank1.
0: disabled
1: enabled
bit[1]: rank1 ODT
bit[0]: rank0 ODT
This parameter is used to determine whether to enable the write ODT pins of other ranks when rank0 is written.
Note: This parameter can be configured in channel mode only, that is, the ODT is configured for a single channel in rank mode.

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_QOSCFG1
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_QOSCFG1 is DDRC QoS algorithm configuration register 1.

Member.name: idmap_mode
Member.description:
ID mapping mode.
0: The id_map mapping mode configured by the register is used by default.
1: The QoS mapping mode is used. The AXI interface configures this mode in associated mode by running read/write command. This mapping mode is valid only when its macro definition is enabled in the RTL code.

Member.name: id_map
Member.description:
Four bits that are selected based on the bus ID for configuring the QoS.
bit[15:12]: configure bit[3] mapping to the ID
bit[11:8]: configure bit[2] mapping to the ID
bit[7:4]: configure bit[1] mapping to the ID
bit[3:0]: configure bit[0] mapping to the ID
For example, if ID_MAP is set to 0x5320, it indicates that ID[5], ID[3], ID[2], and ID[0] of the bus ID are used for ID mapping and priority configuration.
The DDRC inserts two bits between the eighth bit and ninth bit of the existing 13-bit ID. These two bits indicate the AXI port number. Therefore, the bit width of the ID mapped by the DDRC is 15 bits.
00: AXI port 1
01: AXI port 2
10: AXI port 3
11: AXI port 4

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_CTRL
RegisterGroup.description: MMC_CTRL is an MMC control register.

Member.name: use_internal_dmac
Member.description:
Whether to transfer data by using the IDMAC.
0: The CPU transfers data by using the slave interface.
1: The CPU transfers data by using the IDMAC.

Member.name: enable_od_pullup
Member.description:
External open-drain pull-up.
0: disabled
1: enabled
This value is inverted internally, and then transmitted to the SDIO_CCMD_ODPULLUP_EN_N pin.

Member.name: abort_read_data
Member.description:
Whether to abort the data transfer during data read.
0: invalid
1: After transmitting a suspend command during data read, the software polls the card to check when suspend occurs.
After the suspend occurs, the software sets the bit to 1. This enables the data transfer state machine to be restored to idle state for the next block transfer.
After the state machine restores to the idle status, this bit is cleared automatically.

Member.name: send_irq_response
Member.description:
Transmit interrupt response control.
0: invalid
1: An interrupt request (IRQ) response is transmitted automatically.
After the response is transmitted, this bit is cleared automatically.
To wait for the interrupt generated by the MMC controller, the host transmits the CMD40 command and waits for the interrupt response from the MMC controller. If you do not want the host to keep in the interrupt wait state, set this bit to 1, and transmit the CMD40 command to restore to the idle state.

Member.name: read_wait
Member.description:
Read wait control.
0: disabled
1: enabled
This bit is valid only for the SDIO card that supports the read wait function.

Member.name: dma_enable
Member.description: Reserved. The system uses the IDMAC.

Member.name: int_enable
Member.description:
Global interrupt enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled
The interrupt output is valid only when this bit is valid and the interrupt source is enabled.

Member.name: dma_reset
Member.description:
Soft reset control for the IDMAC.
0: invalid
1: reset the internal DMA interface
This bit is automatically reset after two AHB clock cycles.

Member.name: fifo_reset
Member.description:
Soft reset control for the internal FIFO.
0: invalid
1: reset the FIFO pointer
This bit is reset automatically after the reset operation is complete.

Member.name: controller_reset
Member.description:
Soft reset control for the controller.
0: invalid
1: reset the MMC/SD/SDIO host module

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_PWREN
RegisterGroup.description: MMC_PWREN is a Power_en control register.

Member.name: power_enable
Member.description:
Power control.
0: power off
1: power on
This value is used to drive the SDIO_CARD_POWER_EN pin.

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_CLKDIV
RegisterGroup.description: MMC_CLKDIV is a clock divider register that shows the ratio of the frequency of the moduleoutput clock to the frequency of the input clock. For example, if the module input clock is 40MHz and the register value is set to 1, the output clock is 20 MHz.The clock divider is 2 x N. If the value of N is 0x0, it indicates no frequency division (2 x 0 =0); if the value of N is 0x1, the frequency is divided by 2; if the value of N is 0xFF, thefrequency is divided by 510.

Member.name: clk_divider0
Member.description:
Clock divider 0.
The clock divider is 2 x N. If the value of N is 0, it indicates no frequency division; if the value of N is 0x1, the frequency is divided by 2; if the value of N is 0xFF, the frequency is divided by 510.

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_CLKSRC
RegisterGroup.description: MMC_CLKSRC is a clock source select register of the SD card.

Member.name: clk_source
Member.description: This bit must be set to 0.

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_CLKENA
RegisterGroup.description: MMC_CLKENA is a clock enable register.

Member.name: cclk_low_power
Member.description:
Card low-power control for disabling the card clock.
0: non lower-power mode
1: low-power mode
When the card is idle, the card clock is disabled. This function is used only for the MMC and SD card, because the card clock of the SDIO card must be retained for detecting interrupts.

Member.name: cclk_enable
Member.description:
Card clock enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_TMOUT
RegisterGroup.description: MMC_TMOUT is a timeout register.

Member.name: data_timeout
Member.description: Timeout during the data transfer of the card, in unit of the mmc_clk cycle of the card. The timeout is also the data starvation timeout of the CPU.

Member.name: response_timeout
Member.description: Response timeout, in unit of the mmc_clk cycle of the card.

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_CTYPE
RegisterGroup.description: MMC_CTYPE is a card type register.

Member.name: card_width_0
Member.description:
Bus width of the card.
0: non-8-bit mode
1: 8-bit mode
The details are as follows:
If bit[16] is 1, the bus width of the card is set to 8-bit mode, and the value of bit[0] is ignored.
If bit[16] is 0, the bus width of the card is set to 1-bit mode or 4-bit mode. In this case, the bus width depends on the value of bit[0].

Member.name: card_width_1
Member.description:
Bus width of the card.
0: 1-bit mode
1: 4-bit mode

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_BLKSIZ
RegisterGroup.description: MMC_BLKSIZ is a block size configuration register.

Member.name: block_size
Member.description: Block size. The initial size of each block is 512 bytes.

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_BYTCNT
RegisterGroup.description: MMC_BYTCNT is a block transfer count register.

Member.name: byte_count
Member.description:
Number of transferred bytes. The number must be an integral multiple of the block size.
If the data transfer is not block transfer, this register must be set to 0. In this case, the software needs to transmit a stop or an abort command to control the data transfer.

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_INTMASK
RegisterGroup.description: MMC_INTMASK is an interrupt mask register.

Member.name: sdio_int_mask
Member.description:
SDIO interrupt mask.
0: masked
1: not masked

Member.name: int_mask
Member.description:
Interrupt mask.
0: masked
1: not masked
The definitions of bit[15:0] are as follows:
Bit[15]: end-bit error (read)/write no CRC (EBE)
Bit[14]: auto command done (ACD)
Bit[13]: start-bit error (SBE)
Bit[12]: hardware locked write error (HLE)
Bit[11]: FIFO underrun/overrun error (FRUN)
Bit[10]: data starvation-by-host timeout (HTO)
Bit[9]: data read timeout (DTO)
Bit[8]: response timeout (RTO)
Bit[7]: data CRC error (DCRC)
Bit[6]: response CRC error (RCRC)
Bit[5]: receive FIFO data request (RXDR)
Bit[4]: transmit FIFO data request (TXDR)
Bit[3]: data transfer over (DTO)
Bit[2]: command done (CD)
Bit[1]: response error (RE)
Bit[0]: card detect (CD)

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_CMDARG
RegisterGroup.description: MMC_CMDARG is a command parameter register.

Member.name: cmd_arg
Member.description: Command parameter that is transferred to the card. The command parameter is related to the protocol, and each command corresponds to a command parameter.

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_CMD
RegisterGroup.description: MMC_CMD is a command register.

Member.name: start_cmd
Member.description:
Start control.
0: do not start
1: start a command. After the command is transferred to the card interface unit (CIU), this bit is cleared.
The CPU does not allow you to modify this register. Otherwise, an HLE interrupt is generated.
After transmitting a command, the CPU queries this bit, and transmits the next command when the value of this bit changes to 0.

Member.name: boot_mode
Member.description:
Boot mode.
0: boot mode
1: alternative boot mode

Member.name: disable_boot
Member.description:
Boot disable.
If the software enables this bit and the Start_cmd bit at the same time, the controller aborts the boot operation.
The Enable_boot and Disable_boot bits cannot be enabled at the same time.

Member.name: expect_boot_ack
Member.description:
Boot response enable.
If the software enables this bit and the Enable_boot bit at the same time, the controller detects the boot response signal, that is, "0-1-0" sequence.

Member.name: enable_boot
Member.description:
Boot enable.
This bit is available when the boot mode is mandatory. If the software enables this bit and the Start_cmd bit, the controller pulls down the CMD signal to start the boot process.
The Enable_boot and Disable_boot bits cannot be enabled at the same time.

Member.name: update_clock_registes_only
Member.description:
Automatic update.
0: The normal command sequence is used. That is, the values of MMC_CMD, MMC_CMDARG, MMC_TMOUT, MMC_CTYPE, MMC_BLKSIZ, and MMC_BYTCNT are transferred from the BIU to the CIU. The CIU uses the new values of registers when running new commands.
1: No command is transmitted, and only the clock register values in the card clock domain are updated. The values of MMC_CLKDIV, MMC_CLKSRC, and MMC_CLKENA are transferred to the card clock domain.
The card clock can be changed (frequency change and clock enable) even no command is transmitted.
Each time the card clock is changed, this bit needs to be set to 1. In this case, no command is transmitted to the card, and no CD interrupt is generated.

Member.name: card_number
Member.description: Sequence number of the card that is being used.

Member.name: send_initialization
Member.description:
Whether to transmit the initialization sequence.
0: do not transmit the initialization sequence before transmitting the Send_initialization command (high level in 80 clock cycles)
1: transmit the initialization sequence before transmitting the Send_initialization command
When a card is powered on, the initialization sequence must be transmitted first for initialization. That is, this bit needs to be set to 1.

Member.name: stop_abort_cmd
Member.description:
Whether to transmit the stop/abort command when data is being transferred in open-ended mode or in fixed length mode.
0: do not transmit the stop/abort command
1: transmit the stop/abort command for stopping the current data transfer

Member.name: wait_prvdata_complete
Member.description:
Whether to transmit a command immediately.
0: transmit a command immediately even though the previous data transfer is not complete
1: transmit a command only when the previous data transfer is complete
The typical value is 0. If this bit is set to 0, the transfer status can be read during data transfer, and the interrupt transfer is supported.

Member.name: send_auto_stop
Member.description:
Whether to transmit the stop command.
0: do not transmit the stop command after data transfer
1: transmit the stop command after data transfer
In non-data transfer mode, this bit is ignored.

Member.name: transfer_mode
Member.description:
Transfer mode.
0: block transfer mode
1: stream transfer mode
In non-data transfer mode, this bit is ignored.

Member.name: read_write
Member.description:
Read/write control.
0: read data from the card
1: write data to the card
In non-data transfer mode, this bit is ignored.

Member.name: data_transfer_expected
Member.description:
Data transfer indicator.
0: No data is output from the card.
1: Data is output from the card.

Member.name: check_repsonse_crc_
Member.description:
Whether to perform the CRC check.
0: do not check the CRC response
1: check the CRC response
No valid CRC is returned when some commands are responded. To prevent the host from performing CRC, the software needs to disable this function based on related commands.

Member.name: response_length
Member.description:
Response length.
0: Short responses are output from the card
1: Long responses are output from the card
The length of a long response is 128 bits, whereas the length of a short response is 32 bits.

Member.name: response_expect
Member.description:
Whether to output response.
0: No response is output from the card.
1: Responses are output from the card.

Member.name: cmd_index
Member.description: Command index.

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_RESP0
RegisterGroup.description: MMC_RESP0 is response register 0.

Member.name: response0
Member.description: Bit[31:0] of a response.

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_RESP1
RegisterGroup.description: MMC_RESP1 is response register 1.

Member.name: response1
Member.description:
Bit[63:32] of a long response.
After the CIU transmits an auto-stop command, the corresponding response is stored in this register, and the response to the previous command is still stored in MMC_RESP0.
The auto-stop command is available only during data transfer, and the corresponding response is always a short response.

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_RESP2
RegisterGroup.description: MMC_RESP2 is response register 2.

Member.name: response2
Member.description: Bit[95:64] of a long response.

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_RESP3
RegisterGroup.description: MMC_RESP3 is response register 3.

Member.name: response3
Member.description: Bit[127:96] of a long response.

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_MINTSTS
RegisterGroup.description: MMC_MINTSTS is a masked interrupt status register.

Member.name: sdio_interrupt
Member.description:
SDIO interrupt mask status.
The SDIO interrupt is valid only when MMC_INTMASK [sdio_int_mask] is enabled.
0: No SDIO interrupt is output from the card.
1: An SDIO interrupt is output from the card.

Member.name: int_status
Member.description:
Status of each interrupt.
Bit[15]: end-bit error (read)/write no CRC (EBE)
Bit[14]: auto command done (ACD)
Bit[13]: start-bit error (SBE)
Bit[12]: hardware locked write error (HLE)
Bit[11]: FIFO underrun/overrun error (FRUN)
Bit[10]: data starvation by the host timeout (HTO)
Bit[9]: data read timeout (DTO)
Bit[8]: response timeout (RTO)
Bit[7]: data CRC error (DCRC)
Bit[6]: response CRC error (RCRC)
Bit[5]: receive FIFO data request (RXDR)
Bit[4]: transmit FIFO data request (TXDR)
Bit[3]: data transfer over (DTO)
Bit[2]: command done (CD)
Bit[1]: response error (RE)
Bit[0]: card detect (CD)

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_RINTSTS
RegisterGroup.description: MMC_RINTSTS is a raw interrupt status register.

Member.name: sdio_interrupt
Member.description:
Raw SDIO interrupt status.
0: No SDIO interrupt is output from the card.
1: An SDIO interrupt is output from the card.
The value of the interrupt status bit is independent of the interrupt mask status.

Member.name: int_status
Member.description:
Raw status of each interrupt. Writing 1 clears the bits, and writing 0 has no effect. The value of the interrupt status bit is independent of the interrupt mask status.
Bit[15]: end-bit error (read)/write no CRC (EBE)
Bit[14]: auto command done (ACD)
Bit[13]: start-bit error (SBE)
Bit[12]: hardware locked write error (HLE)
Bit[11]: FIFO underrun/overrun error (FRUN)
Bit[10]: data starvation by the host timeout (HTO)
Bit[9]: data read timeout (DRTO)/boot data start (BDS)
Bit[8]: response timeout (RTO)/boot ACK received (BAR)
Bit[7]: data CRC error (DCRC)
Bit[6]: response CRC error (RCRC)
Bit[5]: receive FIFO data request (RXDR)
Bit[4]: transmit FIFO data request (TXDR)
Bit[3]: data transfer over (DTO)
Bit[2]: command done (CD)
Bit[1]: response error (RE)
Bit[0]: card detect (CD)

RegisterGroup.name: MMC_STATUS
RegisterGroup.description: MMC_STATUS is a status register.

Member.name: fifo_count

Member.name: response_index

Member.name: data_state_mc_busy
Member.description:
0:The data transmit/receive state machine is idle.
1:The data transmit/receive state machine is busy.

Member.name: data_busy
Member.description:
0: idle
1: busy

Member.name: data_3_status
Member.description:
0: There is no card.

Member.name: commandfsm_states
Member.description:
Status of the command state machine.
0x0: idle
0x1: send initialization sequence
0x2: Tx CMD start bit
0x3: Tx CMD tx bit
0x4: Tx CMD index+arg
0x5: Tx CMD crc7
0x6: Tx CMD end bit
0x7: Rx resp start bit

0x9: Rx resp tx bit
0xA: Rx resp CMD idx

Member.name: fifo_full
Member.description:
FIFO full flag.

1: full

Member.name: fifo_empty
Member.description:
FIFO empty flag.
